exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press (Flat)
exercises.description: A fundamental upper body compound exercise that involves pressing a barbell from chest level while lying on a flat bench.
instructions: Lie flat on the bench with feet planted firmly on the ground
Grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, palms facing away
Lift the bar off the rack and position it directly above your chest with arms extended
Lower the bar to your chest in a controlled manner while keeping elbows at approximately 45 degrees
Press the bar back up explosively to the starting position, locking out at the top
tips: Retract your shoulder blades and keep them pinned to the bench throughout
Maintain a slight arch in your lower back with chest up
Keep your feet planted and drive through them for stability
common_mistakes: Flaring elbows out too wide (increases shoulder injury risk)
Bouncing the bar off the chest
Lifting hips off the bench during the press

exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press (Incline)
exercises.description: A bench press variation performed on an inclined bench that emphasizes the upper chest and front deltoids.
instructions: Set the bench to a 30-45 degree incline angle
Lie back on the bench with feet flat on the floor
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width with palms facing away
Lower the barbell to your upper chest area with control
Press the barbell up and slightly overhead until arms are fully extended
tips: A 30-45 degree angle is optimal for upper chest activation
Keep elbows tucked at approximately 45 degrees to protect shoulders
Activate your glutes to maintain a solid foundation
common_mistakes: Setting the incline too steep (over 45 degrees shifts emphasis to shoulders)
Allowing the bar to drift too far forward
Not maintaining full body tension

exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press (Decline)
exercises.description: A bench press variation performed on a declined bench that targets the lower portion of the chest.
instructions: Set the bench to a decline position with feet higher than head
Secure your feet under the foot pads for stability
Grip the barbell with hands wider than shoulder-width
Lower the bar to your lower chest area in a controlled motion
Press the weight back up to full arm extension
tips: Focus on keeping tension in the lower pecs throughout the movement
Maintain control as the decline position increases difficulty
Keep shoulder blades retracted
common_mistakes: Lowering the bar too high on the chest
Using momentum instead of controlled movement
Not securing feet properly leading to instability

exercises.name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Flat)
exercises.description: A chest-building exercise using dumbbells that allows for greater range of motion and works each side independently.
instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand at chest level
Position dumbbells with palms facing forward, elbows bent at 90 degrees
Press both dumbbells upward until arms are fully extended above chest
Lower the dumbbells with control until they're level with your chest
Press back up to the starting position
tips: Keep dumbbells at equal height throughout the movement
Maintain stable shoulder blade position against the bench
Allow for a greater stretch at the bottom than barbell press
common_mistakes: Allowing dumbbells to drift too far apart or together
Losing control at the bottom of the movement
Not maintaining equal tempo on both sides

exercises.name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Incline)
exercises.description: An incline dumbbell press that targets the upper chest with independent arm movement for balanced development.
instructions: Set bench to 30-45 degree incline and sit with back against the pad
Hold dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing forward
Press dumbbells up and together in an arc motion until arms are extended
Lower dumbbells slowly to just below shoulder level
Maintain tension and press back to starting position
tips: Keep core engaged and feet planted firmly
Don't let dumbbells move further apart as you lower
Stop the dumbbells in line with each ear rather than bringing them together completely
common_mistakes: Setting incline too steep (reduces chest activation)
Lowering dumbbells too far causing shoulder strain
Using excessive momentum

exercises.name: Dumbbell Chest Fly
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that stretches and contracts the chest muscles through a wide arc motion.
instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding dumbbells above chest with palms facing each other
Maintain a slight bend in elbows throughout the movement
Lower dumbbells out to sides in an arc motion until arms are parallel to ground
Squeeze chest to bring dumbbells back together above chest
Stop when dumbbells are in line with ears, not touching at the top
tips: Think about hugging a tree to maintain proper arc motion
Keep shoulder blades retracted against the bench
Use significantly lighter weight than pressing movements
common_mistakes: Lowering dumbbells below chest level (increases injury risk)
Bending elbows too much (turns into a press)
Bringing dumbbells all the way together at top (loses tension)

exercises.name: Cable Crossover
exercises.description: A cable exercise that provides constant tension on the chest muscles throughout the movement.
instructions: Set cable pulleys to appropriate height (high for lower chest, middle for middle chest, low for upper chest)
Grab handles with palms facing forward and step into the center
Lean slightly forward with one foot ahead for balance
Pull handles down and together in front of chest with slight elbow bend
Hold contraction briefly then return to starting position with control
tips: Imagine hugging a tree with your arms
Maintain stable torso position throughout
Focus on chest contraction rather than arm movement
common_mistakes: Using momentum or swinging the weight
Letting elbows bend too much during movement
Standing too upright (reduces chest activation)

exercises.name: Push-ups
exercises.description: A classic bodyweight exercise that builds chest, shoulder, and tricep strength.
instructions: Start in plank position with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width
Keep body in a straight line from head to heels
Lower your body until chest nearly touches the ground
Keep elbows at 45-degree angle from body
Push back up to starting position maintaining rigid core
tips: Engage core and squeeze glutes to maintain straight body position
Don't let hips sag or pike up
Breathe in on the way down, out on the way up
common_mistakes: Letting hips sag creating lower back arch
Not lowering chest close enough to ground
Flaring elbows out too wide
Straining neck by looking forward instead of down

exercises.name: Machine Chest Press
exercises.description: A fixed-path pressing movement that targets the chest with built-in stability.
instructions: Adjust seat so handles are 2 inches below shoulders
Sit with back, glutes, and lower back firmly against the pad
Grip handles with feet planted firmly on the ground
Press handles forward while squeezing chest at the top
Return handles to starting position with control
tips: Keep shoulder blades squeezed against the back pad
Drive feet into floor for stability
Don't lock out elbows completely at the top
common_mistakes: Setting seat height incorrectly
Allowing shoulders to round forward
Using momentum instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Chest Dips
exercises.description: A bodyweight exercise that emphasizes the lower chest and triceps when performed with forward lean.
instructions: Grip dip bars and lift yourself to starting position with arms extended
Lean torso forward and bring chin to chest
Bend legs backwards and allow elbows to flare slightly outward
Lower body until upper arms are parallel to floor (90-degree angle)
Press back up to starting position without fully locking out elbows
tips: Greater forward lean increases chest activation
Use a wider grip for more chest emphasis
Keep slight hollow in lower back
common_mistakes: Staying too upright (shifts focus to triceps)
Going below 90 degrees (increases shoulder strain)
Fully locking out elbows at top

exercises.name: Barbell Row (Bent Over)
exercises.description: A fundamental back-building compound exercise that develops thickness in the lats and upper back.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding barbell with overhand grip
Hinge at hips with slight knee bend until torso is at 45-degree angle
Keep back straight and core braced throughout
Pull barbell to lower chest/upper abdomen by driving elbows back
Squeeze shoulder blades together at the top, then lower with control
tips: Focus on pulling with elbows, not hands
Keep the bar close to your body throughout the movement
Maintain neutral spine—don't round the back
common_mistakes: Rounding the back (increases injury risk)
Standing too upright (reduces range of motion)
Using momentum instead of controlled pulling

exercises.name: Pendlay Row
exercises.description: An explosive barbell row variation where the bar returns to the floor between reps, emphasizing power and back strength.
instructions: Stand with barbell on floor and feet hip-width apart under the bar
Hinge at hips to 90 degrees with torso parallel to floor
Grip barbell with overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width
Explosively pull the bar to base of chest/lower ribcage
Lower bar back to floor completely before starting next rep
tips: Brace core hard and keep back flat throughout
Think about pulling the bar to your hips
Drive feet into floor as you pull
common_mistakes: Not returning bar fully to floor between reps
Allowing hips to rise during the pull
Elevating shoulders instead of pulling with lats

exercises.name: Dumbbell Row (Single Arm)
exercises.description: A unilateral rowing exercise that builds lat strength and size while allowing focus on each side independently.
instructions: Place right hand and right knee on flat bench with left leg stepped out to side
Keep back straight and parallel to ground
Grab dumbbell with left hand, arm fully extended
Row dumbbell up to side until upper arm is parallel with floor
Lower slowly back to starting position and repeat, then switch sides
tips: Pull the dumbbell toward your hip, not your chest
Keep torso stable—avoid rotating
Think about driving your elbow to the ceiling
common_mistakes: Rotating torso during the row
Pulling weight to chest instead of hip
Using momentum instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Pull-ups
exercises.description: A bodyweight exercise using an overhand grip that primarily targets the back muscles with emphasis on lats.
instructions: Grip pull-up bar with hands wider than shoulder-width, palms facing away (pronated grip)
Hang with arms fully extended and engage core
Pull yourself up by driving elbows down toward hips
Continue until chin clears the bar
Lower yourself with control back to full arm extension
tips: Think about pulling your elbows down rather than pulling yourself up
Keep chest up and shoulder blades retracted
Avoid swinging or using momentum
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range of motion at bottom or top
Kipping or swinging to generate momentum
Shrugging shoulders up toward ears

exercises.name: Chin-ups
exercises.description: A vertical pulling exercise using an underhand grip that emphasizes biceps and lats with a narrower grip.
instructions: Grip bar with hands shoulder-width apart, palms facing toward you (supinated grip)
Hang with arms fully extended
Pull yourself up by contracting biceps and lats
Continue until chest reaches or clears the bar
Lower with control to starting position
tips: Narrower grip allows for more bicep and chest recruitment
Generally easier than pull-ups due to increased bicep involvement
Keep movement controlled without swinging
common_mistakes: Not lowering to full arm extension
Using momentum to complete reps
Not engaging lats properly

exercises.name: Lat Pulldown (Wide Grip)
exercises.description: A cable machine exercise using a wide grip that isolates the latissimus dorsi muscles.
instructions: Sit on lat pulldown machine and adjust knee pad to secure thighs
Grip bar with overhand grip, hands wider than shoulder-width
Lean back slightly (about 30 degrees) with chest out
Pull bar down to upper chest by driving elbows down and back
Slowly return bar to starting position with arms fully extended
tips: Focus on pulling with your lats, not your arms
Keep chest up and maintain slight backward lean
Pull bar to upper chest, not behind neck
common_mistakes: Pulling bar behind neck (increases injury risk)
Using excessive body swing
Not achieving full range of motion at top

exercises.name: Lat Pulldown (Close Grip)
exercises.description: A lat pulldown variation using a V-handle attachment that provides greater range of motion and targets mid-back.
instructions: Attach V-handle to lat pulldown machine and adjust knee pad
Grip V-handle with neutral grip (palms facing each other)
Sit with core engaged and slight backward lean
Pull handle down toward upper chest until it passes chin height
Slowly extend arms to return handle to starting position
tips: Pull elbows down toward hips rather than straight down
Don't pull the grip down too low (stops at upper chest)
Focus on squeezing lats at the bottom
common_mistakes: Pulling attachment down to waist (shifts work to shoulders and forearms)
Using momentum instead of controlled movement
Not maintaining core tension

exercises.name: Seated Cable Row
exercises.description: A horizontal pulling exercise that develops thickness in the middle back and lats.
instructions: Sit on cable row machine with feet on platform and knees slightly bent
Grip handle attachment with both hands and sit upright with neutral spine
Pull handle toward belly button while keeping torso stationary
Squeeze shoulder blades together at the end of the movement
Slowly extend arms to return to starting position
tips: Think about pulling your elbows toward your hips
Keep torso perpendicular to floor (beginners) or allow slight stretch forward (advanced)
Avoid excessive backward lean
common_mistakes: Swinging torso back and forth
Rounding the spine
Using arms instead of back muscles to pull

exercises.name: Face Pulls
exercises.description: A cable exercise that targets the rear deltoids, upper back, and rotator cuff muscles.
instructions: Set cable to chest height and attach rope handle
Grip rope with neutral grip (palms facing each other)
Step back with shoulder-width or staggered stance
Pull rope toward face while separating the rope ends
Keep elbows high and pointed upward as you pull
tips: Focus on external rotation of shoulders at end of movement
Use higher reps (12-15) as this targets slow-twitch muscle fibers
Squeeze rear delts at peak contraction
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing form
Letting elbows drop below shoulder level
Not externally rotating at the shoulders

exercises.name: T-Bar Row
exercises.description: A compound rowing movement that builds back thickness and strength with a stable, angled bar position.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart straddling the bar
Hinge at hips with knees slightly bent and back neutral
Grip handles (wide for lats, narrow for mid-back)
Pull bar toward lower chest by driving elbows back
Squeeze shoulder blades together then lower with control
tips: Keep chest low and parallel to floor for full range of motion
Brace core throughout to protect lower back
Think about pulling elbows toward ceiling
common_mistakes: Standing too upright (reduces range of motion)
Allowing back to curve forward
Using momentum instead of controlled pulls

exercises.name: Deadlift (Conventional)
exercises.description: A foundational compound lift that develops the entire posterior chain including back, glutes, and hamstrings.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, barbell over midfoot
Hinge at hips and grip bar just outside legs with hands
Lower hips, chest up, back flat, shoulders over or slightly in front of bar
Brace core, engage lats, and push floor away with feet to lift bar
Stand fully upright with hips and knees locked, then lower bar with control
tips: Think 'leg press the earth away' rather than pulling the bar
Keep bar close to body throughout—it should drag up shins
Maintain neutral spine—don't round back
common_mistakes: Rounding the back at any point in the lift
Starting with hips too low or too high
Not maintaining full-foot contact with ground
Letting bar drift away from body

exercises.name: Straight Arm Pulldown
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that targets the lats through a long range of motion with straight arms.
instructions: Attach rope or bar to high pulley on cable machine
Stand facing machine with feet shoulder-width apart and slight knee bend
Grip attachment with arms extended overhead, feeling lat stretch
Drive arms down in arc motion toward hips while keeping arms straight
Slowly return to starting position maintaining tension
tips: Bend hips back to 30-45 degree angle for proper positioning
Think about pulling with lats, not arms
Excellent for improving deadlift strength and lat engagement
common_mistakes: Bending elbows during the movement
Using momentum or swinging
Not achieving full stretch at top position

exercises.name: Overhead Press (Barbell)
exercises.description: A fundamental shoulder-building exercise that develops all three deltoid heads and overhead strength.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, barbell at shoulder height
Grip bar just outside shoulders with palms facing forward
Brace core and squeeze glutes, maintaining slight upper back arch
Press bar overhead in straight line, moving head slightly back to clear bar
Lock out at top with bar over center of body, then lower with control
tips: Shrug shoulders at top to engage traps and protect rotator cuff
Keep elbows pointed forward and down under wrists
Don't arch lower back excessively—squeeze glutes to prevent this
common_mistakes: Excessive lower back arching
Letting elbows flare out to sides
Pressing too far forward or behind body
Not reaching full elbow extension at top

exercises.name: Overhead Press (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: A shoulder press using dumbbells that allows for natural arm movement and independent work for each side.
instructions: Stand or sit with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing forward
Brace core and maintain neutral spine
Press dumbbells overhead until arms are fully extended
Keep dumbbells moving in straight vertical path
Lower dumbbells back to shoulder height with control
tips: Can be performed seated to reduce core involvement and isolate shoulders
Keep wrists neutral and locked in position
Avoid letting dumbbells drift too far forward or back
common_mistakes: Arching lower back excessively
Not pressing dumbbells in vertical line
Letting one side lag behind the other

exercises.name: Arnold Press
exercises.description: A shoulder press variation with rotation that targets all three deltoid heads with increased range of motion.
instructions: Sit or stand with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing toward you
Press dumbbells up while simultaneously rotating wrists outward
Finish with arms extended overhead and palms facing forward
Reverse the movement by rotating palms back while lowering
Return to starting position with palms facing you at shoulder level
tips: The rotation targets rear delts in addition to front and side delts
Start with lighter weight than standard shoulder press
Move smoothly through the rotation
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing control of rotation
Not completing full range of motion at bottom
Rushing through the movement

exercises.name: Lateral Raise (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that targets the side deltoids to build shoulder width.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, dumbbells at sides with palms facing body
Maintain slight bend in elbows throughout movement
Raise arms out to sides, leading with elbows
Lift until arms are parallel to ground (shoulder height)
Lower dumbbells with control back to starting position
tips: Lead with elbows, not hands—elbows should be higher than hands
Raise dumbbells 20 degrees in front of chest, not straight out to sides
Use lighter weight and focus on form over load
3-second count up, 3-second count down
common_mistakes: Using momentum or swinging weights
Leading with hands instead of elbows
Going above shoulder height unnecessarily
Bending at waist

exercises.name: Front Raise (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that primarily targets the front deltoids.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells in front of thighs, palms facing downward or toward body
Brace core and maintain neutral spine
Raise dumbbells forward in arc motion until arms are parallel to floor
Keep arms extended with slight elbow bend throughout
Lower dumbbells slowly back to starting position
tips: Can be performed alternating arms for each repetition
Keep torso stationary—don't lean back
Stop at shoulder height, no need to go higher
common_mistakes: Using momentum by swinging weights
Leaning back to assist the lift
Raising dumbbells too high above shoulder level

exercises.name: Rear Delt Fly (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: An isolation movement that targets the often-neglected rear deltoids.
instructions: Hinge forward at hips with slight knee bend until torso is nearly parallel to floor
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging down, palms facing each other
Raise dumbbells out to sides with slight elbow bend
Squeeze shoulder blades together at top of movement
Lower dumbbells with control back to starting position
tips: Keep back flat and core engaged throughout
Lead with elbows, not hands
Focus on rear delt contraction rather than weight used
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing form
Not maintaining bent-over position
Letting upper back do the work instead of rear delts

exercises.name: Upright Row (Barbell)
exercises.description: A pulling exercise that targets shoulders and traps by lifting the barbell vertically along the body.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding barbell at waist with overhand grip
Grip width slightly narrower than shoulder-width
Pull barbell up along body toward chin, leading with elbows
Keep elbows higher than wrists throughout movement
Lower barbell slowly back to starting position
tips: Wider grip works side deltoids more; narrower grip targets traps
Don't raise bar above upper chest/chin level
Engage shoulders and traps, avoid using lower back
common_mistakes: Using lower back to lift weight
Raising bar too high (increases shoulder impingement risk)
Swinging weight instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Cable Lateral Raise
exercises.description: A cable variation of lateral raises that provides constant tension throughout the movement.
instructions: Set cable pulley to lowest position and attach handle
Stand beside cable machine and grip handle with far hand
Maintain slight elbow bend and raise arm out to side
Lift until arm is parallel to ground at shoulder height
Lower with control back to starting position
tips: Cable provides constant tension unlike dumbbells
Can perform one arm at a time for better focus
Lead with elbow, not hand
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing form
Leaning away from cable
Not controlling the eccentric (lowering) portion

exercises.name: Barbell Curl
exercises.description: A fundamental biceps exercise using a straight barbell to build arm size and strength.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding barbell with underhand grip
Start with arms fully extended, barbell at thigh level
Keep elbows tight to sides and curl bar up toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at top of movement
Lower bar with control to full arm extension
tips: Keep elbows stationary—don't let them move forward
Avoid swinging or using momentum
Full range of motion from complete extension to full contraction
common_mistakes: Swinging weight using back and hips
Letting elbows drift forward
Not lowering to full arm extension
Using wrists instead of keeping them neutral

exercises.name: EZ Bar Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl using an EZ bar with angled grips that reduces wrist strain.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding EZ bar with underhand grip on angled sections
Arms fully extended with bar at thigh level
Keep elbows pinned to sides and curl bar toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at top, avoiding backward lean
Lower bar slowly to full extension before next rep
tips: Angled grip allows semi-supinated position that's easier on wrists
Wide grip emphasizes bicep width; narrow grip targets bicep peak
Maintain straight wrists—can slightly cock away from body for advanced lifters
common_mistakes: Swinging elbows forward
Using momentum instead of bicep strength
Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Dumbbell Curl
exercises.description: A biceps exercise using dumbbells that allows for natural arm movement and independent work.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells at sides, arms fully extended, palms facing forward
Keep elbows close to body throughout movement
Curl dumbbells toward shoulders, keeping upper arms stationary
Squeeze biceps at top of movement
Lower dumbbells with control to starting position
tips: Can be performed alternating arms or simultaneously
Rotate pinkies toward ceiling as you curl for maximum contraction
Keep shoulders back and core engaged
common_mistakes: Swinging weights using momentum
Letting elbows drift away from sides
Not controlling the descent

exercises.name: Hammer Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl variation using neutral grip that targets the brachialis and brachioradialis.
instructions: Stand or sit with dumbbells at sides, palms facing each other (neutral grip)
Keep upper arms and elbows close to body
Curl dumbbells toward shoulders maintaining neutral grip throughout
Pause at top and squeeze biceps and forearms
Lower with control to starting position
tips: Neutral grip activates forearms and deeper bicep muscles (brachialis)
Targets upper and outer bicep for balanced arm development
Can perform seated to limit momentum
common_mistakes: Rotating wrists during movement
Using momentum to lift weight
Allowing elbows to move away from body

exercises.name: Preacher Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl performed on a preacher bench that emphasizes the lengthened position of the biceps.
instructions: Adjust bench so chest is flush against pad with armpits wedged in
Extend arms over pad and grip weight with underhand grip
Curl weight up, rotating pinkies toward ceiling
Stop before forearms are perpendicular to maintain tension
Lower weight below 90 degrees to emphasize lengthened position
tips: Emphasizes lengthened-position tension which is crucial for bicep growth
Keep elbows on pad throughout—lifting them invites shoulder flexion
Don't let weight rest on bench at any point during set
common_mistakes: Lifting elbows off the pad
Going to full perpendicular position (loses tension)
Using too much weight and cheating form

exercises.name: Concentration Curl
exercises.description: A seated biceps isolation exercise that eliminates momentum and emphasizes peak contraction.
instructions: Sit on bench with dumbbell between legs
Place upper arm (triceps) against inner thigh with arm perpendicular to ground
Make fist with opposite hand and extend to side for balance
Curl dumbbell up with control, keeping wrist neutral
Squeeze biceps hard at top without leaning back, then lower slowly
tips: Wedge upper arm into thigh, not just elbow
Upper arm should stay perpendicular to ground throughout
Emphasize squeeze at top for peak biceps development
common_mistakes: Wedging elbow instead of upper arm into thigh
Leaning back as you curl
Curling too high causing triceps to lose thigh contact

exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl performed on an incline bench that maximizes stretch on the long head of the biceps.
instructions: Set bench to 45-60 degree incline and sit with back against pad
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging behind body, palms facing forward
Keep upper arms stationary and curl dumbbells toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at top of movement
Lower slowly with control to maximize eccentric stretch
tips: 45-degree angle provides optimal stretch on long head of biceps
Arms behind body creates greater range of motion than standing curls
Longer eccentric portion enhances hypertrophy
common_mistakes: Setting incline too low (negates benefits)
Letting upper arms move forward during curl
Not lowering to full extension

exercises.name: Tricep Pushdown (Cable)
exercises.description: A cable isolation exercise that targets all three heads of the triceps with constant tension.
instructions: Set cable pulley to high position and attach straight bar or rope
Stand facing machine with feet hip-width apart, slight knee bend
Grip attachment with elbows pinned to sides at 90 degrees
Push bar/rope down by extending only at elbows until arms are straight
Return to starting position with control
tips: Keep elbows tight to sides—they shouldn't move
Focus on tricep extension, not pressing with shoulders
Can use rope attachment for slightly different angle
common_mistakes: Allowing elbows to drift forward or flare out
Using shoulders and upper body to press weight
Not achieving full extension at bottom

exercises.name: Skull Crushers (Lying Tricep Extension)
exercises.description: A lying triceps exercise that builds mass by allowing heavy weight with focus on tricep extension.
instructions: Lie on flat bench with barbell or dumbbells held with arms perpendicular to chest
Grip EZ bar or dumbbells with hands at shoulder-width
Lower weight toward forehead by bending only at elbows
Extend arms back to starting position using triceps
Can lower above head for greater long head emphasis and constant tension
tips: EZ bar grip reduces wrist stress and emphasizes lateral head
Extending arms further back overhead targets long head more
Keep upper arms stationary throughout
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to sides
Moving upper arms instead of just forearms
Dropping weight too fast risking head injury

exercises.name: Overhead Tricep Extension (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: A triceps exercise performed overhead that emphasizes the long head of the triceps.
instructions: Stand or sit holding dumbbell overhead with both hands cupping one end
Extend arms fully overhead to starting position
Brace core and pull belly button toward pelvis
Lower dumbbell behind head by bending only at elbows
Extend arms back to starting position by squeezing triceps
tips: Keep upper arms stationary—only forearms should move
Can perform seated to reduce lower back stress
Standing version engages core more
common_mistakes: Overextending lower back
Allowing upper arms to move forward
Using too much weight and losing form

exercises.name: Dips (Tricep Focus)
exercises.description: A bodyweight exercise emphasizing the triceps through an upright body position.
instructions: Grip dip bars and lift to starting position with arms extended
Keep body upright with head facing forward
Extend legs downward and keep elbows close to body
Lower body by bending elbows until upper arms are parallel to floor
Press back up using triceps without fully locking elbows
tips: Upright torso maximizes tricep activation
Narrow grip emphasizes triceps more than wide grip
Don't go below 90-degree angle to protect shoulders
common_mistakes: Leaning forward (shifts emphasis to chest)
Letting elbows flare out
Fully locking out elbows at top

exercises.name: Close-Grip Bench Press
exercises.description: A bench press variation with narrow grip that emphasizes triceps while still engaging chest.
instructions: Lie on flat bench and grip barbell with hands closer than shoulder-width
Position bar over chest with arms extended
Lower bar to mid-chest keeping elbows tucked close to sides
Press bar back up focusing on tricep extension
Lock out at top and repeat
tips: Keep elbows tucked at approximately 30-45 degrees from body
Don't grip too narrow as this can strain wrists
Excellent for building tricep mass and lockout strength
common_mistakes: Gripping too narrow causing wrist pain
Letting elbows flare out wide
Bouncing bar off chest
